headline: The State of the Union
summary: Read President Barack Obama's remarks, as prepared for delivery.

headline: Graphic: Analysis of the State of the Union
summary: Read President Barack Obama's remarks, as prepared for delivery.

headline: CD Yields Unchanged
summary: Yields on certificates of deposit were mostly unchanged in the latest week.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: The Many States of the Union
summary: Read about past State of the Union addresses.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Feb. 12, 2013

headline: Queensland Green Lights Shale Project
summary: Australia's Queensland state will allow companies to develop oil deposits trapped in shale rock formations, it said, improving the outlook for the country's oil production, which is on the decline.

headline: G-7 Attempts to Avoid Currency War
summary: A statement from the Group of Seven leading economies on Tuesday attempted to head off a potentially destabilizing round of currency devaluations, but comments aimed at elaborating on it left currency traders puzzled.

headline: Rangers Blow Lead, but Win
summary: The New York Rangers recovered after blowing a three-goal lead in the third period to beat the Bruins 4-3 in Boston Tuesday night.

headline: Devils Cool Off as Win Streak Ends
summary: The New Jersey Devils have been hot, but the Carolina Hurricanes has been playing well lately, too. The Hurricanes upended the Devils, 4-2, on Tuesday night, snapping the Devils' five-game win streak.

headline: Pro-Gun Rally Hits Cuomo
summary: More than 600 opponents of New York's new gun-control laws rallied Tuesday at the state Capitol, vowing to disobey the firearms restrictions signed last month by Gov. Andrew Cuomo, and push for their repeal.

headline: New Zealand Dollar Lower Against Aussie, Flat Against Greenback
summary: The New Zealand dollar dipped against the Australian dollar Wednesday after better-than-expected Australian consumer confidence data, but remained largely rangebound against the U.S. dollar after opening higher.

headline: Obama to Halve Afghan Force in Next Year
summary: Obama has decided to cut the size of the U.S. force in Afghanistan by half over the next year in an acceleration of the U.S. departure.

headline: Midtown New York Push
summary: The hippest and fastest-growing companies operating in New York are expanding in trendy neighborhoods such as the Meatpacking District and Union Square. So why is Scott Rechler busy buying towers in pinstriped Midtown?

headline: South Ferry Options Explored
summary: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority could restart limited train service to the South Ferry subway station in lower Manhattan far earlier than previously thought, the agency's transit chief said Tuesday.

headline: Theater Stages Signature Dinner
summary: Supporters of the Signature Theatre moved through each of the institution's three venues during dinner Monday. Along the way, a jazz trio, traditional Chinese dancers and the zany, angelic Nellie McKay entertained them.

headline: Cameras Keep a Close Watch on the Police
summary: Police in Albuquerque, N.M., routinely carry pistols and bullet-proof vests to defend themselves. But now they are adding a piece of equipment that could help defend their reputation: video cameras on their lapels.

headline: Independent Designers Show Off New Fashions
summary: Fashion Week is never short on style and sparkling energy, but it does sometimes lack a stage for independent designers to shine, according to Brooklyn Royalty designer and Manufacture New York founder Bob Bland.

headline: 'Kindie' Set Rocks the House
summary: The Grammys aren't just about dangerously cut dresses and pyrotechnics . One of those categories is children's music, and several of the nominees gathered over the weekend for a concert.

headline: Road by Road, Plows Reopen Cities, Towns
summary: Life appeared to be returning to normal in the region Tuesday as plow crews reopened hundreds of snow-packed roadways that had been made impassable by last weekend's historic blizzard.

headline: A 102-Year-Old Condo-Boom Victim
summary: Falling sales and soft prices are spooking Toronto's condo market, but for Sydney Bacon, a 102-year-old World War II veteran, and other critics of the boom, it is a little bit of a breather.

headline: The Skinny on Off-the-Runway Pigging Out
summary: New York Fashion Week conjures up images of statuesque models, pin-thin editors and size-zero frocks. But behind the skinny catwalk, the event has a chubby little secret: It is a nine-day smorgasbord of free food and open bars.

headline: Turning Back the Clock
summary: The classic luncheonette returns to Midtown in the newly open Skylight Shoppe, the latest effort at Maloney & Porcelli.

headline: New Jersey Fund Move Could Clarify Prices
summary: The murky world of real-estate pricing by private-equity funds is about to become a little less murky, thanks in large part to New Jersey's state pension fund, which disclosed last month that it is putting on the block $1 billion of its positions in private-equity funds.

headline: A Simmering Bake-Off
summary: François Payard at FP Patisserie and Maison Kayser opened recently on opposite sides of the street.

headline: Obama Turns Focus to Boosting US Economy
summary: President Barack Obama, delivering his State of the Union address, returns to the themes that animated his re-election campaign, putting forth a mix of old and new proposals aimed at invigorating the economy and boosting the middle class.

headline: Thai Militants Killed in Raid on Military Base
summary: At least 16 Islamist militants dressed as government troops were killed in a botched middle-of-the-night attack on a Thai military base early Wednesday.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Feb. 13, 2013

headline: The State of the Union
summary: President Barack Obama delivered his State of the Union address Tuesday.

headline: For China, Spending Is Harder Than It Looks
summary: Even if China's leaders want to offer tax cuts and boost spending this year, they may have less fiscal room to do so than official statistics suggest.

headline: Obama Seeks Safer Cyber Networks
summary: Obama unveiled an executive order to establish a system of voluntary cybersecurity standards, directing federal agencies to take action after White House-backed legislation failed last year.

headline: Old Marriott Deal Gets New Scrutiny
summary: A little-known deal negotiated in 1998 allows the Marriott Marquis hotel, in the heart of Times Square, to purchase the city-controlled land beneath it for nearly $20 million in 2017.

headline: Europe Remains Challenge for Church
summary: As Pope Benedict XVI prepares to relinquish his office, church leaders planning for a new pontiff are sure to deliberate over one of his longtime goals: replenishing Europe's deserted pews.

headline: Minimum-Wage Debate Brought Back to the Fore
summary: President Obama's proposal to raise the federal minimum wage is likely to rekindle debates over whether the measure helps or hurts low-income workers.

headline: Michigan Wants Wider Control of Its Schools
summary: State leaders in Michigan are again looking to expand an education initiative that takes poor-performing schools out of local hands and bands them together in a single statewide district.

headline: Mr. Rogers' Classics and Tiger Love
summary: On Thursday's special Valentine's Day episode of "Daniel Tiger's Neighborhood," which airs on PBS Kids, the singer-songwriter Jason Mraz will perform the opening and closing songs.

headline: Shore Shifted by Storm
summary: Like it or not, Jersey Shore residents are awakening to the reality that the beloved summer destination is undergoing a transformation never before seen.

headline: Michigan Tries to Expand Schools Initiative
summary: State leaders in Michigan are renewing efforts to expand an education initiative that takes poor-performing schools out of local hands and bands them together in a single statewide district with a less-structured curriculum and a nonunion workforce.

headline: Korean Blast Fans Nuclear Concerns
summary: North Korea's nuclear test drew withering international criticism. The U.N. called it a clear threat" to peace and security and pledged action.

headline: Senate Panel Backs Hagel Nomination
summary: The Senate Armed Services Committee approved the nomination of Chuck Hagel as defense secretary, sending Obama's pick to the full Senate for a vote.

headline: Redisovering the Voices of a Generation
summary: The newly released "Smith Tapes" resurrect the legacy of Howard Smith, who interviewed just about every iconic figure of the 1960s on his ground-breaking WPLJ radio show.

headline: The Pop Scene: Masters of Rock, Staples of Soul
summary: This week's Pop Scene calendar leads off with Hoboken's finest, Yo La Tengo, at the Town Hall, plus Toro y Moi at Webster Hall, Jim James in Williamsburg, Mavis Staples at Lincoln Center, and more.

headline: Banks Delay $208 Million In Sandy Cash
summary: Banks are holding $208 million in insurance proceeds owed to New York state homeowners whose properties were damaged in superstorm Sandy.

headline: Treatment of Prostate Is Revisited
summary: Men diagnosed with high-risk prostate cancer can significantly cut the length of time they are treated with testosterone-blocking hormone therapy without affecting their long-term survival, researchers reported Tuesday.

headline: Girardi's Crucial Year, With Less Firepower
summary: New York Yankee manager Joe Girardi vowed Tuesday that his team can win 95 games and go to the World Series, despite losing several key pieces of last year's team.

headline: A New Push for Entrepreneur Visas
summary: Dozens of entrepreneurs are lobbying for legislation that would grant visas to immigrants starting businesses in the U.S.

headline: A Healthy Ace Is a Tradable One
summary: Why do the New York Mets need a healthy Johan Santana? Sure, he's their ace but he could be a valuable commodity on the trade market, and the Mets could command a package of top prospects for his services.

headline: Sequester Looms, No Deal in Sight
summary: Senate Democrats and Republicans squared off Tuesday over whether to try to block across-the-board spending cuts set to begin March 1.

headline: CFTC Delays Swaps Vote Amid Concerns
summary: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission delayed a vote on establishing trading venues for complex derivatives that exacerbated the 2008 financial crisis, as the agency's swing vote voiced concerns about the plan's market repercussions.

headline: Wrestling: What the Games Are About
summary: Most of us long made peace with the professionalization and corporatization of the Olympic Games, but there was at least the comfort that, in sports like wrestling, the Olympics still represented the pinnacle, Jason Gay writes.

headline: Sea-Lion Strandings Baffle Southern California
summary: Sickly sea-lion pups have been getting stranded in record numbers on the coast of Southern California this winter, overwhelming marine-rescue centers and surprising residents.

headline: Intel to Launch Web TV Service
summary: Intel confirmed plans to offer a paid video service delivered over the Internet, which will come along with a new-style set-top box sold to consumers.

headline: Judges May Face Prison for Fixing Tickets
summary: Two former judges in Philadelphia's Traffic Court, which has been plagued by allegations of rampant corruption, pleaded guilty to fixing tickets in a continuing sweeping criminal probe.

headline: Revel Casino Hires Restructuring Experts
summary: Revel, the struggling Atlantic City casino, has hired restructuring lawyers and bankers to mull options for reworking a heavy debt load.

headline: What If It Snows at the Super Bowl?
summary: Next year's Super Bowl will be played outdoors at MetLife Stadium in New Jersey, which has recently seen much snow and ice. That's raised the question of whether the NFL has contingency plans for bad weather.

headline: States Gear Up to Pitch Health Plans
summary: Supporters of the 2010 health law are looking for ways to persuade millions of uninsured, skeptical Americans to sign up for health plans this fall.

headline: Brewer May Deserve an Encore
summary: The New York Knicks have cooled off since their hot start. Putting the forgotten Ronnie Brewer back in the rotation may be one solution to the team's malaise.

headline: Devils Tickets Are Hotter Than Hades
summary: The New Jersey Devils are a hot ticket. Going into Tuesday's home game, the Devils had sold out five of their first six games this season at Prudential Center in Newark.

headline: Hunt for Yield Sows Junk-Bond Boom
summary: Yield-seeking investors have developed an appetite for European junk. The shift is a boon for scores of European companies, many in places previously shut out of the market.

headline: Mixed Messages Rattle Yen

headline: Drug Manager Can't Stop Its Takeover Habit
summary: Pharmacy-benefit manager Catamaran is growing at a pace that most companies would envy. But steering such an enterprise can create management headaches. CEO Mark A. Thierer discusses takeover prospects, the new health-care law and competitive pressures.

headline: Digging Out of a $38 Billion Hole
summary: Soon after Tom Albanese became Rio Tinto's CEO in 2007, he bought Alcan for $38.1 billion. But the biggest mining deal ever came at a cyclical peak, and the company has been contending with a tumble in aluminum prices ever since.

headline: Syria Opposition Says It Was Target of Blast
summary: Turkey said that an explosion on its border with Syria that killed 14 people a day earlier was a terrorist attack, while senior Syrian dissidents who had been traveling in the area said they believed they had been the target.

headline: Wrestling Is Thrown to the Mat
summary: Wrestling is one of nine sports that was contested in the first modern Olympics in 1896. And yet, the International Olympic Committee's executive board moved to eliminate wrestling from the 2020 Olympic Games Tuesday.

headline: Soccer Club Mirrors Brazilians' Rising Fortunes
summary: In a few short years, the Corinthians have gone from rags to riches, a symbol of the growing clout of Brazil's long-neglected lower to middle classes.

headline: Firms Circle Back to Lower Borrowing Costs
summary: In the world of corporate borrowing, it rarely gets better than this.

headline: Holdouts Aim to Dell-ete Original Bid
summary: Holding out could help Dell investors squeeze more out of its would-be buyers. Though only a little, if history is any guide.

headline: Jenkins: Gun Control That Works
summary: Cities aren't gun-free without politicians willing to take the heat to make them so.

headline: Plots & Ploys
summary: Credit Suisse is eyeing a new Manhattan home...A bank took control of the Kansas City Fed's former home after a developer's plans for condos failed...And a Highland Capital Management LP group aims to overhaul Turtle Bay Resort in Oahu.

headline: On GE's Watch
summary: Take a look back at some of NBC's hit television shows.

headline: Burger King Adds More Coffee
summary: Burger King, playing catch-up with McDonald's, is doubling the number of coffee items on its menu.

headline: Casino Revamp Banks on U.S. Program
summary: A closed Las Vegas landmark that was a Rat Pack hangout in its glory days may get a makeover through a federal program that offers green cards to foreign investors.

headline: Abe Urges Firms to Boost Wages
summary: In a twist to his campaign to end deflation, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe called on companies to raise employee wages in a meeting with the country's biggest business leaders.

headline: Indonesia Takes Aim at Terror Financing
summary: Indonesia passed a long-awaited bill that gives the government new powers to cut off lines of terrorist financing, including by freezing bank accounts and seizing assets.

headline: French Hint at Lower Growth Forecasts
summary: France's president laid the groundwork Tuesday for lowering the country's growth forecasts as the state auditor warned Paris will likely miss this year's deficit targets.

headline: The College Basketball Bio as Term Paper
summary: Everyone knows that Duke basketball coach Mike Krzyzewski is very good at his job. But in case you wanted to brush up on all he's accomplished before the Blue Devils take on North Carolina Wednesday, here's a warning: It'll take a while.

headline: T. Rowe Price Opposes Dell Buyout
summary: Fund manager T. Rowe Price, one of Dell's largest investors, said it  plans to vote against a plan to take the company private, arguing the offer is too low.

headline: Sotheby's Sells Bacon for $21.5 Million
summary: The contemporary art market chugged ahead Tuesday at a $116.4 million Sotheby's sale in London, led by a $21.5 million Francis Bacon triple portrait purchased by a longtime German collector.

headline: Timothy Beardson: Don't Count on China to Bail Out the U.S.
summary: Beijing's net investment in U.S. Treasurys over the past two years is essentially zero.

headline: Bruce Feirstein: Mr. July, Your Drone Is Ready
summary: The Counterterrorism 2013 Calendar is a grim but quirky reminder of the times we live in.

headline: Are You Hard-Wired to Boil Over?
summary: Hotheads, take note: Research says people who experience extreme reactions to stress, from a racing heart to full-blown rage, may be conditioned from early-childhood experiences.

headline: Brady and Lehrman: A Lincolnian Economic Primer for Obama
summary: Abe's approach was to provide rules of the road for the private sector and let entrepreneurs compete.

headline: George Weigel: Catholics Need a Pope for the 'New Evangelization'
summary: The next pontiff must nurture Catholicism where it is growing and revive it where it is not.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: President Abraham Lincoln on America's finances in 1862.

headline: The Push for Grown-Up 'Squeezies'
summary: Packets filled with fruit and vegetable purée have become a hit with babies, toddlers and kids in the past few years. Now pouch makers are marketing them as a way for adults to snack on the go.

headline: Avon Brings Cash Back Home, Takes Tax Hit
summary: Avon may bring back some of its overseas cash to cover funding needs at home, joining a select group of companies changing their minds about money held abroad.

headline: Race Heats Up to Sell Upscale SUVs
summary: Jaguar Land Rover last year grabbed the industry spotlight in the sport-utility vehicle market with its Range Rover Evoque and now wants to double-down with a vehicle costing twice as much.

headline: BlackRock Names New CFO
summary: BlackRock said it has hired a new chief financial officer from Morgan Stanley, as the money manager's current chief financial officer takes on a new role at the company.

headline: Michael Kors Profit Soars
summary: Michael Kors fiscal third-quarter earnings surged as the specialty retailer continued to enjoy strong demand for its high-end clothing and accessories. It also continued to open stores.

headline: Does It Rain a Lot in Manchester, Too?
summary: Eddie Johnson, the Seattle Sounder and U.S. men's national team player, says there's one area in which MLS is at least the equal of Europe's top soccer leagues: the stadiums.

headline: Organic Growth Limited, Even at Whole Foods
summary: : There is little doubt Whole Foods can grab a larger share of the "yuppie dollar," but there are limits.

headline: What's Selling Where | Roses
summary: Could a rose by any other name still make a great Valentine's Day bouquet? Online floral retailer FTD shared its most popular rose arrangements by city.

headline: A Savage Continent
summary: Ragged, disease-ridden and hungry soldiers, unleashed on the civil population, spelled catastrophe during Europe's centuries of incessant war. Henrik Bering reviews Lauro Martines's "Furies."

headline: Legg Mason Names Sullivan CEO
summary: Legg Mason said interim CEO Joseph Sullivan will remain in that post permanently, ending a months-long search that stretched across Wall Street.

headline: Helping the Help
summary: Sue Shellenbarger answers a reader's question on Social Security payments for domestic workers.

headline: Producers Head to Court to Battle J.P. Morgan Copper ETF
summary: Two big copper consumers in the U.S. launched a legal challenge to the creation of a J.P. Morgan exchange-traded fund that would hold the metal.

headline: CEOs Fly Coach? Travel Turns Frugal
summary: Business travel is back to pre-recession levels, but road warriors can expect less legroom.

headline: Betsey Johnson Fall 2013
summary: Betsey Johnson launched an active-wear line during her fall runway show.

headline: Saving the Soul of Mali
summary: To the musicians from Mali, the attempt by terrorists to suppress music in their country's north goes beyond politics and religion: It's an offense to the soul of the nation, where music is essential to life.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Rain Falls on Wheat's Parade
summary: Wheat prices fell to a seven-month low as rain and snow in the southern Great Plains eased concerns over drought in the region.

headline: Black and White and Noir
summary: "Dark Crimes: Film Noir Thrillers" contains three bedrocks of the genre—two starring Alan Ladd and Veronica Lake—and all three derived from material written by masters of crime fiction.

headline: More Than Just the Girl
summary: A splendid sampling from one of the world's finest collections of Dutch Golden Age works. If only the exhibition's name wasn't such an advertising gimmick.

headline: Goodyear, Michelin Lower Profit Views
summary: Goodyear Tire & Rubber and Michelin warned that weakness in Europe auto markets would reduce their earnings outlooks for the year.

headline: Yen Jumps on G-7 Confusion
summary: The yen surged from an almost three-year low against the dollar, after Group of Seven officials said meetings later this week will address recent weakness in the currency.

headline: State of the Union Prize: an Aisle Seat
summary: A seat along the center aisle at the State of the Union speech is a chance to shake hands with the president in front of millions of viewers, and perhaps share a private word. But it means staking out a seat hours in advance.

headline: Seeking the End of a Starter Problem
summary: Jonathan Welsh answers a reader's question about a Toyota Land Cruiser that is on its fourth new starter.

headline: Photos of the Day: Feb. 12
summary: In today's pictures, baseball players limber up in Florida, a samba dancer gets a lift in Brazil, lightning strikes St. Peter's Basilica in the Vatican, and more.

headline: Financial Shares Provide a Boost
summary: Financial shares led major stock indexes to five-year highs, putting the Dow industrials 1% away from their record close.

headline: Berlin Project Lures Tech Start-Ups
summary: An unused brewery on the death strip that once bordered the Berlin Wall is being converted to a hub for start-up companies in a development that highlights Berlin's efforts to stoke its burgeoning technology industry.

headline: Equity Financial Winds Down FX Operations, Nine Laid Off, CEO says
summary: Equity Financial plans to wind down Equity Financial FX, its Toronto foreign-exchange operation, and will lay off nine employees, the parent company's chief executive says.

headline: Uncovering Hidden Disability Benefits
summary: If you have a disability policy, you might be unaware of a valuable feature potentially worth tens of thousands of dollars.

headline: When Bill Collectors Knock
summary: Borrowers could become the target of a new breed of aggressive debt collectors. Here's how to handle them.

headline: Finding the Top Dog
summary: An Affenpinscher named Banana Joe won Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Tuesday.

headline: EIA Expects Slim U.S. Oil-Demand Growth
summary: U.S. demand for crude oil dropped to a 16-year low in 2012 and is expected to rise only marginally through 2014, government forecasters said.

headline: Senate Passes Domestic Violence Bill
summary: The U.S. Senate easily passed a domestic violence bill, as negotiators worked to overcome Republican objections in the House.

headline: Apple Defends Position on Cash
summary: Apple Chief Executive Tim Cook defended the company's distribution of cash to its shareholders and called the proxy fight with a prominent investor a "silly sideshow."

headline: Wrestling Dropped From Olympics
summary: Leaders of the International Olympic Committee have dropped wrestling from the Olympic program, a surprise decision that removes one of the oldest sports from the 2020 Games.

headline: Freeport LNG, BP Sign  Long-Term Export Contract
summary: Freeport LNG Expansion LP has signed an agreement allowing a BP PLC unit to export 4.4 million metric tons a year of liquefied natural gas out of its terminal in Freeport, Texas.

headline: ConnectOne Bancorp Climbs in Debut
summary: Community-bank chain ConnectOne Bancorp led off the week's slate of initial public offerings with a 5.9% gain.

headline: Canadian Dollar Firmer
summary: The Canadian dollar modestly strengthened against its U.S. counterpart, boosted amid gains in commodities and equity markets, and by a final green light on Cnooc's $15.1 billion acquisition of Nexen.

headline: Treasurys Hold Onto Losses
summary: Treasury prices extended their losing streak into a second-straight session, pressured by an onslaught of new debt sales and higher stocks.

headline: Shell Faces Challenges from Damaged Rigs
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's plans to send its two offshore drilling rigs to Asia for extensive repairs will likely mean the cancellation of its second summer of drilling in the U.S. Arctic Ocean

headline: Coca-Cola's Profit Rises 13%
summary: Coca-Cola's fourth-quarter profit rose 13% as the soft-drink maker's case volume increased, while the impact of foreign exchange hurt its revenue growth.

headline: Natural Gas Slides 1.5%
summary: Natural-gas futures fell as temperature forecasts offered mixed signals about gas-fired heating demand.

headline: ETFs a Boon to Advisers, Says Fund-Business Giant
summary: Jack Brennan, chairman emeritus of fund manager Vanguard Group, thinks ETFs are helpful to financial advisers, reports AdvisorOne.

headline: Senior UBS Banker to Exit
summary: The head of UBS's noncore division is to depart the Swiss bank. Carsten Kengeter ran the firm's investment bank during a period of instability and losses.

headline: Orange-Juice Futures Jump 5.4%
summary: Orange-juice futures surged over 5% to a more than six-week high on concerns about production, while raw sugar slipped to a 2½-year low.

headline: Barclays's Unconvincing Makeover
summary: Barclays boss Antony Jenkins wants the world to believe that his strategic plan marks a radical break for the U.K. bank. But strip away the public-relations waffle about cultural revolution, and what has actually changed?

headline: Pope Underwent Surgery for Pacemaker
summary: Pope Benedict XVI was fitted with a pacemaker before his election in 2005 and recently underwent surgery to recharge it, a Vatican spokesman said.

headline: Toronto Condos Cool
summary: Toronto's once red-hot condominium market is suddenly teetering as sales plummet and prices ease.

headline: Special-Effects Studio to File Chapter 11
summary: Special-effects studio Rhythm & Hues, nominated for an Oscar for its work on "Life of Pi," plans to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, one of its lawyers said.

headline: Massachusetts Urges Ban on Arbitration Clauses for Advisers
summary: Massachusetts's securities regulator is urging the Securities and Exchange Commission to ban a mandatory arbitration clause often found in contracts between registered investment advisers and their clients.

headline: The 'Stanford Junior' on My Masters
summary: In his review of Edward Ball's "The Inventor and the Tycoon" (Bookshelf, Feb. 7) Simon Winchester refers to Leland Stanford's "eponymous California university," but the university was actually named for Gov. Stanford's dead son

headline: A Conservationist vs. Conservation
summary: Regarding Kimberley A. Strassel's "A Jewell Who's Rough on Jobs" (Potomac Watch, Feb. 8): Rough on jobs? Maybe, but ironically, that's nothing compared with the devastating effect Sally Jewell and her boss, President Obama, are having on the wilderness.

headline: Voter-ID Laws: Useless, Burdensome
summary: Historian Thomas Fleming's "A Jersey Lesson in Voter Fraud" (op-ed, Feb. 6) wistfully harkens back to a time when voter fraud ran rampant in his hometown of Jersey City, N.J., as well as President Obama's hometown of Chicago.

headline: Washington Isn't a Credible Choice for Pension Reform
summary: Carl DeMaio calls on Washington to step in and force the reform of public-employee pension plans that threaten to depress or bankrupt many states and cities ("Revoking the Federal Free Pass on Pensions," op-ed, Feb. 7).

headline: New York Pet Fashion Show
summary: Canine couture was on display at the ninth annual New York Pet Fashion Show on Friday, with proceeds benefiting nonprofit organization Animal Haven Rescue.

headline: Currency Wars May Claim Confidence Casualty
summary: If investors were already concerned about a currency war, the Group of Seven's attempt to calm their fears may have done the opposite.

headline: Our Failing the Mentally Ill Has High Societal Costs
summary: Regarding E. Fuller Torrey's "Fifty Years of Failing America's Mentally Ill" (op-ed, Feb. 5): Four years ago, our schizophrenic son went off his meds. He was hospitalized four times and picked up by the police for a variety of infractions.

headline: 'Tween' Retailer Justice Becomes Doll Launchpad
summary: Toy makers are turning to tween-focused retail chain Justice—which focuses on girls between the ages of 7 and 12—to launch their newest fashion dolls.

headline: Hercules Offshore Swings to Fourth-Quarter Profit
summary: Embattled driller Hercules Offshore Inc. posted its first profit in five years as energy production in the U.S. Gulf of Mexico roared back to life in 2012, prompting strong demand for shallow-water drilling rigs.

headline: OECD Urges Tax Overhaul
summary: A report prepared for this week's meeting of G-20 countries could add backing to efforts by the governments of the U.K., Germany and France to stop big multinationals from using loopholes to shift profits to low-tax countries.

headline: Budget Surplus Posted for January
summary: The U.S. budget posted a rare January surplus, reflecting a big boost in tax revenue, the Treasury Department said.

headline: A Look Back at Wrestling in the Olympics
summary: The IOC cut wrestling from the program for the 2020 Olympics on Tuesday, a stunning rebuke for a sport that goes back to the inaugural modern games in 1896 and has produced champions including Karelin, Gardner and Baumgartner.

headline: Banks Push Up European Stocks
summary: European stocks gained ground as well-received profit figures from Barclays, combined with news of the lender's plans for an overhaul, pushed banking stocks higher. Currencies gyrated amid confusion over the Group of Seven nations' stance on the yen's recent decline.

headline: State of the Tea Party
summary: For the third year in a row, the Tea Party Express will sponsor their own State of the Union response.

headline: Sequester Fairy Tale
summary: The White House story about the automatic budget cuts keeps changing.

headline: Cuomo's Fracking Decision
summary: By Allysia Finley  New York's popular Democratic governor may be calculating that he doesn't need support from independents and Republicans.
